_accidents.CF_Other: Contractor failure to follow procedures during tie-in

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Kentucky Distribution Center recognizes management's responsibility in protecting its employees, the public, the environment, equipment and property.  The safety and health of all personnel are very important.  The control of accidents has been and will continue to be a basic responsibility of all personnel in the Louisville facility.

To accomplish the company's goal in preventing accidents the facility has established a Facility safety Program.  The objectives of the program are to maximize safety performance, eliminate human suffering resulting from injuries and accidents and reduce losses associated with damage of property.

One of the activities associated with the Facility Safety Program has been the development and implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency response programs which are designed to comply with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standards (29 CFR 1910.119) and EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) regulation (40 CFR Part 68).  Mr. Larry Slauenwhite, Maintenance Manager, is responsible for implementation of these programs.

The purpose of the accidental release prevention and emerency response programs is to prevent the occurrence and minimize the consequences of significant releases of toxic substances as well as fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.  Overall, these programs help prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and environmental and property damage which may result from such occurrences.

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs help prevent accidents because they focus on rules,procedures and practices which govern individual processes, activities or pieces of equipment.  These rules are detailed and improved as necessary.  They are also communicated to and accepted by all employees at the facility.

In addition to the Facility Safety Program the Kentucky Distribution Center follows these co

rporate safety guidelines:

Employee Handbook of Safety Rules
Kroger Contractor Safety Rules
Kroger Safety Inspection and Abatement Plans
Safety Process Improvement Teams
Behavioral Accident Prevention Process (BAPP) Steering Committee

B.  Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The facility is a distribution center warehouse storing grocery items, perishable and frozen food products for distribution to retail outlets.  The facility operates an anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system for maintaining appropriate storage temperatures for produce and frozen food storage.  The amount of ammonia contained in the system is in excess of 10,000 lbs.  System maximum inventory is ~31,000 lbs.  Since an ammonia release from the system could cause adverse on and off site health and environmental effects the facility is subject to both OSHA Process Safety Management (29 CFR 1910.119) and EPA Risk Management Program (40 CFR Part 68) regulations.  The facility is subject to Program 3 level requirements of the EPA RMP regulations.

C.  Summary of Worst Case and Alternative Release Scenarios

The worst case release scenario at the Kentucky Distribtuion center involves the release of 12,000 lbs of ammonia over a 10 minute period due to the failure of the control pressure receiver (CPR-1).  This quntity represents the maximum capacity of the receiver.  Under worst case atmospheric conditions the ammonia could present a health hazard to the public to a distance of 1.2 miles.  This distance was determined using the methodology proscribed by the EPA RMP Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration.

The worst case scenario is unlikely for the following reasons:

Worst case weather conditions are rare
Industry standards and good engineering practices were followed in the design and installation of the system
The receiver is located in a low traffic area within an Engine Room designed to industry standards
Ammonia is not corrosive in this service and the vessel is relatively new
Ammonia

detectors are located in the Engine Room in the vicinity of the vessel
Pressure relief valves limit pressures to below vessel design specs
The facility has a Preventive Maintenance and Inspection program in place
The facility has a training program to ensure that Operators are qualified to maintain and operate the vessel and system
Facility Emergency Response Procedures are designed to enable rapid response to and isolation of any release

The alternative release scenario developed for the facility involves the release of 1,140 lbs of ammonia over a 60 minute period through a defective pressure safety valve (PSV) on the CPR-1 receiver which lifts to releive high system pressure but fails to reseat properly.  Under the alternative weather conditions ammonia could pose a health risk to a distance of .10 miles.  This distance was determined using the methodology proscribed by the EPA RMP Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration.

The alternative release scenario is considered unlikely for the following reasons:

Industry standards and good engineering practices were followed in the design and installation of the system
The system is operated at a considerably lower pressure than the relief pressure
Ammonia is not corrosive in this service
The facility has a preventive maintenance and inspection program for maintenance and testing of the relief valves
The facility has a training program to ensure that Operators are qualified to maintain and operate the vessel and system
Facility Emergency Response Procedures are designed to enable rapid response to and isolation of any release

D.  Description of the Accidental Release Prevention Program

The prevention program consists of the following elements:

Employee Participation:  Employees operating and maintaining the system are involved in the establishment and implementation of all phases of the program. They are involved inall Process Hazard Analyses and Incident Investigations.

Process Safety Information:  Written information h

as been collected which enables the employees to identify and understand the potential hazards in the system.  The written information includes the ammonia MSDS and a description of the desing of the operating system components, safety devices and systems, and operations.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA):  Formal studies using the What-If Checklist technique have been conducted to examine the system and determine potential failures and failure prevention procedures, equipment and systems.  Recommendations arising from the PHAs are tracked and addressed.

Operating Procedures:  Written, detailed procedures have been developed which describe the steps to be followed to safely operate the system.

Training:  A training program has been developed which ensures that employees aretrained on all aspects of the system and on the duties which they should perform to ensure the safe operation of the system.

Contractors:  All contractors are screened and evaluated before they perform work on or near the ammonia system.  The contractors are also periodically evaluated to ensure that they are working safely.

Pre-Startup Safety Review:  Pre-startup Reviews are required for all new ammonia related equipment and systems to verify that all information is in place, that appropriate reviews have been conducted, that equipment is installed properly and that procedures and training are in place prior to start-up.

Mechanical Integrity:  Maintenance and inspection procedures have been eveloped and put in action to ensure that equipment and systems operate properly and that they are inspected in an appropriate frequency and manner.  Records of maintenance and inspections are kept and periodically evaluated.

Hot Work Permit:  These procedures ensure that a signed permit is obtained prior to peformance of any Hot Work.  A Line Break procedure has also been developed for use when any activity involves breaking into any line or equipment contianing ammonia.

Management of Change:  Procedures

are designed to enusre that all changes made to the ammonia refrigeration system are properly reviewed and documented.

Incident Investigation: Incident investigation teams are formed to investigate iIncidents and accidents involving the ammonia system. Recommendations for improvement and prevention are developed, tracked and resolved.

Compliance Audits:  PSM compliance audits are conducted every three years to ensure that the program is in place and funcitoning properly.  Audit recommendations are documented, tracked and resolved.

E.  Five Year Accident History

There has been one one ammonia related incident at the facility within the past five years which has resulted in a serious on-site effect.  A releae of ~80 lbs of ammonia occurred on 6/30/2001 during a system expansion project which resulted in non-severe injuries to 5 employees.  The release was the result of a contrator's failure to follow safety procedures.  The incident resulted in no signiiant off site exposure and was invesigated using Incident Investigation procedures.  Steps have been taken to prevent recurrence.

F.  Description of the Emergency Response Program

On and Off site emergency response procedures have been developed and implemented at the facility.  The procedures describe howfacility employees, response teams and management will respond in the event of an ammonia related emergency.  The procedures incude  incident discovery, notifications, responses, evacuations - on and off site, community response and agency coordination.  The facility has installed a community alert siren for use in ammonia releases.

G.  Planned changes to Improve Safety

The following changes are planned to improve safety conditions and further strengthen the ongoing safety efforts at the Kentucky Distribution Center:

Hiring of additional Operators/Mechanics
Increased employee involvement in evacuation and emergency planning
